children.value: This page will walk you through a series of GraphQL queries, each designed to demonstrate a particular feature of GraphQL. You’ll be querying the
so feel free to experiment and poke around the innards of the site! You can also open the
You’ll be using GraphiQL, an interactive editor you can also use
Let’s start with the basics, pulling up the site
. Here the query is on the left and the results are on the right.
Try editing the query to include the
. When typing in the query editor you can use
Gatsby structures its content as collections of
, which are connected to each other with
. In this query you ask for the total count of plugins in this Gatsby site, along with specific information about each one.
) to get extended details from the
There are several ways to reduce the number of results from a query. Here
is used to show only the first three.
Skip over a number of results. In this query
is used to omit the first 3 results.
(not equals) operator is used to show only results that have a title. A good video tutorial on this is
to enable MongoDB-like query syntax for object filtering. This allows Gatsby to support operators like
and querying nested fields through the
It is also possible to filter on multiple fields - just separate the individual filters by a comma (works as an AND):
filter: { contentType: { in: ["post", "page"] }, draft: { eq: false } }
are filtered to find the book that has
in its title and belongs to the
You can also combine the mentioned operators. This query filters on

children.value: In the playground below the list, there is an example query with a description of what the query does for each operator.
, must match the given data exactly
, must be different from the given data
which acts as a placeholder for any non-empty string
, must be an element of the array
, must NOT be an element of the array
, must be greater than given value
, must be greater than or equal to given value
, must be less than given value
, must be less than or equal to given value
, this indicates that the field you are filtering will return an array of elements, on which you can apply a filter using the previous operators
If you want to understand more how these filters work, looking at the corresponding
in the codebase could be very useful.
The ordering of your results can be specified with
. Here the results are sorted in ascending order of
You can also sort on multiple fields but the
keyword can only be used once. The second sort field gets evaluated when the first field (here:
) is identical. The results of the following query are sorted in ascending order of
) but in the first query (only one sort field) the latter comes after the first. The additional sorting on the
will be sorted in ascending order. Optionally, you can specify a sort
per field by providing an array of
(for descending) values. For example, to sort by
in ascending order, and additionally by
in descending order, you would use
. Note that if you only provide a single sort
value, this will affect the first sort field only, the rest will be sorted in default ascending order.
Dates can be formatted using the
to format the dates. This allows you to use any tokens in your string. See
You can also pass in a
to adapt the output to your language. The above query gives you the english output for the weekdays, this example outputs them in german.
anotherDate(formatString: "dddd, MMMM Do YYYY, h:mm:ss a") # Sunday, August 5th 2018, 10:56:14 am
function. The former returns a string generated with Moment.js’
function, the latter returns the difference between the date and current time (using Moment.js’

children.value: This query combines sorting, filtering, limiting and formatting together.
In addition to adding query arguments directly to queries, GraphQL allows to pass in “query variables”. These can be both simple scalar values as well as objects.
The query below is the same one as the previous example, but with the input arguments passed in as “query variables”.
To add variables to page component queries, pass these in the
You can also group values on the basis of a field e.g. the title, date or category and get the field value, the total number of occurrences and edges.
The query below gets us all authors (
) who wrote a book and how many books (
) they wrote. In addition we’re grabbing the
of the author’s books. You can see for example that

Fragments are a way to save frequently used queries for re-use. To create a fragment, define it in a query and export it as a named export from any file Gatsby is aware of. A fragment is available for use in any other GraphQL query, regardless of location in the project. Fragments defined in a Gatsby project are global, so names must be unique.
The query below defines a fragment to get the site title, and then uses the fragment to access this information.
Want to run two queries on the same datasource? You can do this by aliasing your queries. See below for an example:
When you use your data, you will be able to reference it using the alias instead of the root query name. In this example, that would be
